evidence.text:
First Cause of Action
Ultra Vires (Violation of Foreign Service Labor-Management Relations Statute/ Separation of Powers)
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: Ultra Vires

evidence.text: 22 U.S.C. § 4103(b). Comparable, although not identical, language appears in Chapter 71 which allows the President to exclude not just “subdivisions” of agencies from collective bargaining under the statute, but entire agencies themselves. 5 U.S.C. § 7103(b).
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: Foreign Service Labor-Management Relations Statute (22 U.S.C. § 4103(b))

evidence.text: A. Declaring that Sections 1(b) and 3 of the March 27, 2025 Executive Order are unlawful and null and void.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: Plaintiff: Declare Executive Order unlawful

evidence.text: C. Enjoining Defendant Rubio and all his agents and subordinates from implementing Sections 1(b) and 3 of the March 27, 2025 Executive Order.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: Plaintiff: Enjoin implementation of Executive Order

evidence.text: E. Enjoin Defendants State, USAID, and Rubio from continuing to fail to recognize AFSA as the exclusive representative... and order their agents and subordinates to restore AFSA’s collective bargaining agreements with State and USAID and to honor the agreements’ provisions.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: Plaintiff: Restore collective bargaining agreements

evidence.text: F. Awarding Plaintiff reasonable attorney fees and costs incurred.

evidence.text: On March 27, 2025, Defendant Trump issued Executive Order No. 14,251, Exclusions from Federal Labor-Management Programs, 90 Fed. Reg. 14553 (Mar. 27, 2025), which invoked § 4103(b) and terminated the collective bargaining rights of all the Foreign Service members employed by the Department of State and USAID... The White House issued a 'fact sheet' simultaneously with the Executive Order in which it candidly admitted that the President’s Executive Order was issued to curtail the power of and to punish those particular labor organizations who, like AFSA, have ostensibly 'obstructed' the President’s efforts to illegally dismantle the Federal government and to illegally dismiss large segments of the Federal workforce these labor organizations represent.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: President Trump issued Executive Order 14,251 on March 27, 2025, excluding Department of State and USAID from collective bargaining rights under the Foreign Service Labor-Management Relations Statute, citing national security concerns while the White House Fact Sheet admitted retaliation against unions opposing his agenda.

evidence.text: On February 7, Judge Nichols issued a temporary restraining order against the administrative leave and recall. ... On March 21, AFSA and others filed suit against the Administration in U.S. District Court in the Southern District of New York to enjoin the disbandment of the U.S. Agency for Global Media (USAGM), which employs 16 Foreign Service members represented by AFSA. On March 28, U.S. District Judge Oetken issued a temporary restraining order prohibiting 'any further attempt to terminate, reduce-in-force, place on leave, or furlough any USAGM employee.'
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: Plaintiff filed Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief on April 7, 2025, referencing prior temporary restraining order in related case (Amer. Foreign Serv. Assn. et al v. Trump, No. 1:25-cv-352 (CJN))

event.doc_name: Memorandum of Points and Authorities Supporting Plaintiff American Foreign Service Association's Motion for Preliminary Injunction
Memorandum of Points and Authorities Supporting Plaintiff American Foreign Service Association's Motion for Preliminary Injunction

evidence.text: On April 25, 2025, in a related case, the Court issued a preliminary injunction enjoining implementation of Section 2 of the Executive Order, which excluded numerous agencies and subdivisions from the Federal Service Labor-Management Relations Statute. See Nat'l Treasury Emps. Union v. Trump, Civil Action No. 25-0935 (PLF), 2025 WL 1201696 (D.D.C. Apr. 25, 2025) (Order); Nat'l Treasury Emps. Union v. Trump, Civil Action No. 25-0935 (PLF), 2025 WL 1218044 (D.D.C. Apr. 28, 2025) (Opinion).
evidence.source_document: Opinion

add_extracted.value: Nat'l Treasury Emps. Union v. Trump, Civil Action No. 25-0935 (PLF), 2025 WL 1201696 (D.D.C. Apr. 25, 2025) (Order)

evidence.text: On April 25, 2025, in a related case, the Court issued a preliminary injunction enjoining implementation of Section 2 of the Executive Order, which excluded numerous agencies and subdivisions from the Federal Service Labor-Management Relations Statute. evidence.text: Case 1:25-cv-01030-PLF     Document 37     Filed 05/14/25     Page 18 of 36
evidence.source_document: Opinion

add_extracted.value: 05/14/25: Entry of preliminary injunction

evidence.text: the Court denies both of the government’s requests. As to the request to exempt particular agency subdivisions from the preliminary injunction order, the Court denies this request for the reasons explained in Nat’l Treasury Emps. Union v. Trump – namely, the Court’s “conclusions all speak to the fact that [Section 3] of the Executive Order is entirely ultra vires.”
evidence.source_document: Opinion

add_extracted.value: Prohibition on implementation of Executive Order 14,251 and OPM Guidance for State and USAID Foreign Service collective bargaining

evidence.text: the Court, in its discretion, orders AFSA to post a bond in the amount of $100 pursuant to Rule 65(c) of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure.
evidence.source_document: Opinion

add_extracted.value: Requirement for AFSA to post $100 bond

evidence.text: The case is ongoing with a preliminary injunction granted on May 14, 2025, and no settlement is mentioned in any document. The government is appealing the injunction, indicating no settlement has occurred.

evidence.text: The Order Granting Preliminary Injunction (Dkt. 36) does not specify a duration for the injunction, and no other decree duration is mentioned in any document. The case remains pending appeal of the preliminary injunction without any stated expiration.
